Former escort Katina Powell, whose recently published book Breaking Cardinal Rules: Basketball and the Escort Queen exposed alleged sex parties for basketball players and recruits at the University of Louisville, told ESPN's Outside the Lines in an interview that aired Tuesday she felt like part of Louisville's recruitment team. 
"I did everything to make those guys sign. And I felt like, well yea, I brought 'em. Look at what I had to do to get these guys here. I mean, they didn't care anything about U of L. They didn't … it was just U of L. It wasn't nothing spectacular to them. So when you offer what you offer, then of course … I'll sign on the line. If this is what they're giving, they're providing. Sure." 
Powell told ESPN's John Barr that as many as two dozen women danced at the parties for Louisville basketball players, which were overseen by Andre McGee, Louisville's director of basketball operations at the time. USA TODAY Sports' Scott Gleeson explains what's next at Louisville following a reported sex scandal involving Cardinals players and recruits. 
"Andre was the one who always had the money … made it rain," Powell said. "(He) made the deals, paid for the deals. He would start the music and usually the girls would come out one-by-one. And they would dance for the recruit. And he would ask me, 'is there any girls that want to, you know, make extra money?' … that's when I started dealing with McGee." 
One former Louisville recruit who chose to attend a different university told ESPN: "I knew they weren't college girls. It was crazy. It was like I was in a strip club." 
From the ESPN story itself: Outside the Lines reviewed Powell's journals, text messages and phone records and independently confirmed that text messages sent to Powell to arrange the parties came from McGee's cellphone. Further, Outside the Lines said it independently confirmed a wire transfer of money from McGee to Powell on one occasion. 
Powell said the McGee would negotiate and pay for the "side deals," as she called them. 
"The recruit would pick out what girl he wanted. Andre would come to me and tell me what girl the recruit wanted and I would tell the girl," Powell said. "She would say her price. I would tell him. He would say OK. Give me the money and I would sometimes hand it to them. Sometimes he would give it to them. That was just it. He would take them into another room and her and the recruit would do what they do behind closed doors." 
Powell told Outside the Lines that only five or six of the two dozen women did not take part in the "side deals." 
"I just knew side deals was sex," she said. "Side deals were sex and if they wanted to make extra money, that's what the side deal was. Sex." 
Powell specifically named five Louisville recruits -- Montrezl Harrell, Jaquan Lyle, Antonio Blakeney, Jordan Mickey and Terry Rozier – as some who took part in the parties and the side deals. Lyle, Blakeney and Mickey ended up signing with other schools. 
McGee's lawyer, Scott C. Cox, acknowledged on the day the book was released that McGee knows Powell, but he said McGee did not pay anyone to have sex with players or recruits. 
Powell granted Outside the Lines access to her journal of the parties, which she said she kept because she knew "this day would come." USA TODAY Sports discusses the reports of sex parties for basketball players and recruits on the University of Louisville campus. USA TODAY Sports 
"I knew that one day they would say 'she's lying,'" Powell said. "I couldn't make this up if I wanted to. I don't have the need to lie on anyone. … Everything that I'm saying is 100% the truth." 
Powell said that she never met Louisville coach Rick Pitino. But she said she once asked McGee if Pitino knew about the parties and he responded: "He's Rick, he knows about everything." 
"Four years, a boatload of recruits, a boatload of dancers, loud music, alcohol, security cameras, basketball players who came in at will -- how could Rick not know?" Powell said a clip that aired on Good Morning America . 
The University of Louisville and the NCAA are both investigating the allegations and McGee, now an assistant coach at the University of Missouri – Kansas City, has been suspended from his current role pending the investigation.
